 OK, the Declaration of Independence is the one that says our rights are inalienable, not the Constitution.
 
 The main body of the constituiton does not even contain the word "rights."
 
 One of the purposes of the Constitution is to PROTECT our natural rights (as opposed to limiting them). I get this from the preamble where is says: "...secure the Blessings of Liberty to ourselves and our Posterity..."
 
 Despite that, I know of a few "rights" (or liberties) that the federal government will not GRANT me. 
 I cannot grow marijuana (or even hemp) on my private property. 
 I cannot grow coca plants on my private property.
 I also cannot use the natural products that come from these plants.
 I cannot self-prescribe medicines. 
 I cannot use 100% of my personal income, I must pay some of it to the govt.
 The list goes on.
 We don't live in 1776 anymore and haven't for a long time.
 
 Now, maybe the Constitution doesn't "give" us our rights, but I don't think that was anything near what Kerry said. He said "we are the United States." I would think that meant all of us. So he wasn't entirely accurate. Anyway, will you forgive Kerry if I forgive Bush for assuming that the health of every citizen rests on the actions of the CDC?

I'm not supposed to be an expert.
 
 The Constitution (main body) describes in some detail the structure of the government, starting with the Legislature (ART 1), the President (ART 2), the Judiciary (ART 3) and the States (ART 4).
 
 The Amendments mention rights, but mostly say that the rights are not to be denied or infringed. They generally do not list rights as being issued or granted. For instance, in granting the right to vote to 18 year olds, the wording is that "The right of citizens of the United States, who are 18 years of age or older, to vote shall not be denied or abridged by the United States or any state on account of age."
 
 And in "granting" the right to vote to non-whites, "The right of citizens of the United States to vote shall not be denied or abridged by the United States or by any State on account of race, color, or previous condition of servitude."
 
 This way, the writers were acknowledging that their right to vote had always been there...it's time now to say that their rights will no longer be denied.
 
 This is not the same as granting a new right.
Kronus

I'm not supposed to be an expert.

 No one accused you of being one.
 
 

 The Constitution (main body) describes in some detail the structure of the government, starting with the Legislature (ART 1), the President (ART 2), the Judiciary (ART 3) and the States (ART 4).
 
 The Amendments mention rights, but mostly say that the rights are not to be denied or infringed. They generally do not list rights as being issued or granted. For instance, in granting the right to vote to 18 year olds, the wording is that "The right of citizens of the United States, who are 18 years of age or older, to vote shall not be denied or abridged by the United States or any state on account of age."
 
 And in "granting" the right to vote to non-whites, "The right of citizens of the United States to vote shall not be denied or abridged by the United States or by any State on account of race, color, or previous condition of servitude."
 
 This way, the writers were acknowledging that their right to vote had always been there...it's time now to say that their rights will no longer be denied.
 
 This is not the same as granting a new right.

 It's exactly the same as granting a new right, because that's what they did. You seem to be having trouble with verb tenses. The amendment doesn't say "shall no longer be denied", it says "shall not be denied". Future tense. Slaves, or 18 year olds, simply did not have the right to vote. It's not a right that was inherent to them from birth, it was a privledge that they simply didn't have, until the government gave it to them. It's the same with all the rights in the Constitution. We have those rights because the writers of the Constitution decided to include them. If the government didn't feel obligated to honor the right to freedom of speech, for example, they could take it from you very easily by locking you in solitary for the rest of your life. You might keep yourself warm at night telling yourself that your "inalienable" right hadn't been taken away, but that harsh fact would be that it was. Kerry, apparently, understands this. It's not the inalienabliity of your rights that keeps you safe, it's the fact that those rights are spelled out in the Constitution, and the government feels beholden to follow it. If that weren't the case then you could harp on the inalienability of your rights all you like, but the government would still disenfranchise you, censor you, incarcerate you, do whatever they liked. A right you have no ability to excercise is no right at all.

Kronus,
 
 The supreme court has stated on at least a dozen occasions that Jim is correct, the rights recognised in the bill of rights are not created there, merely recognised in that document and those rights were in existance prior to the creation of the document. 
 
 Here is the relevant text from Cruikshank (from findlaw)
 
 
The first and ninth counts state the intent of the defendants to have been to hinder and prevent the citizens named in the free exercise and enjoyment of their 'lawful right and privilege to peaceably assemble together with each other and with other citizens of the United States for a peaceful and lawful purpose.' The right of the people peaceably to assemble for lawful purposes existed long before the adoption of the Constitution of the United States. In fact, it is, and always has been, one of the attributes of citizenship under a free government. It 'derives its source,' to use the language of Chief Justice Marshall, in Gibbons v. Ogden, 9 Wheat. 211, 'from those laws whose authority is acknowledged by civilized man throughout the world.' It is found wherever civilization exists. It was not, therefore, a right granted to the people by the Constitution. The government of the United States when established found it in existence, with the obligation on the part of the States to afford it protection. As no direct power over it was granted to Congress, it remains, according to the ruling in Gibbons v. Ogden, id. 203, subject to State jurisdiction. [92 U.S. 542, 552] Only such existing rights were committed by the people to the protection of Congress as came within the general scope of the authority granted to the national government. 
 
 
 The bill of rights merely recognises pre-existing, natural rights and gives, to some extent, the government the responsibility of protecting those rights.

 Good citation. However, I have to ask where these natural rights were for the Jews in Nazi Germany? Or the dissidents in Soviet Russia? I will agree that there are certain rights that any government would have to grant in order to be considered a decent government, but history has shown us that being decent is not always a high priority for some governments. 
 
 The founders of our country didn't just invent the Constitution from scratch. They were highly educated men, and took the best that the saw from other governments and used it to form our bill of rights. I suppose one could argue that some sort of social evolution would weed out any governement that didn't grant these rights. The dissolution of the Nazis and the Soviets could be cited as an example. That doesn't mean, however, that these rights have some sort of existence outside of a government framework. As your quote says, it "derives its source from those laws whose authority is acknowledged by civilized man throughout the world." The reason we know these rights to be good is not solely because they are in the Constitution, but because these rights have been granted by numerous other governments around the world, down through the ages, and we've seen them to be good.
 
 And by the way, having checked, your quote isn't actually very relevant, is it? The "it" refered to was commerce between states, and not any of the rights granted in the bill of rights. Here's the full quote, for the curious:
 
 "In pursuing this inquiry at the bar, it has been said, that the constitution does not confer the right of intercourse between State and State. That right derives its source from those laws whose authority is acknowledged by civilized man throughout the world. This is true. The constitution found it an existing right, and agve to Congress the power to regulate it. In the exercise of this power, Congress has passed 'an act for enrolling or licensing ships or vessels to be employed in the coasting trade and fisheries, and for regulating the same.'"
 
 Do you have any quotes from the supreme court that actually deal with human rights, and not commerce? Or, alternatively, can you give the full citation for the Cruikshank case that you quote? I'd really like to see it in full. , and couldn't track it down.

 For those who are curious but don't want to see the whole thing, here is the complaint:
 
 
The first count was for banding together, with intent 'unlawfully and feloniously to injure, oppress, threaten, and intimidate' two citizens of the United States, 'of African descent and persons of color,' 'with the unlawful and felonious intent thereby' them 'to hinder and prevent in their respective free [92 U.S. 542, 545] exercise and enjoyment of their lawful right and privilege to peaceably assemble together with each other and with other citizens of the said United States for a peaceable and lawful purpose.' 
 
 The second avers an intent to hinder and prevent the exercise by the same persons of the 'right to keep and bear arms for a lawful purpose.' 
 
 The third avers an intent to deprive the same persons 'of their respective several lives and liberty of person, without due process of law.' 
 
 The fourth avers an intent to deprive the same persons of the 'free exercise and enjoyment of the right and privilege to the full and equal benefit of all laws and proceedings for the security of persons and property' enjoyed by white citizens. 
 
 The fifth avers an intent to hinder and prevent the same persons 'in the exercise and enjoyment of the rights, privileges, immunities, and protection granted and secured to them respectively as citizens of the said United States, and as citizens of the said State of Louisiana, by reason of and for and on account of the race and color' of the said persons. 
 
 The sixth avers an intent to hinder and prevent the same persons in 'the free exercise and enjoyment of the several and respective right and privilege to vote at any election to be thereafter by law had and held by the people in and of the said State of Louisiana.' 
 
 The seventh avers an intent 'to put in great fear of bodily harm, injure, and oppress' the same persons, 'because and for the reason' that, having the right to vote, they had voted. 
 
 The eighth avers an intent 'to prevent and hinder' the same persons 'in their several and respective free exercise and enjoyment of every, each, all, and singular and several rights and privileges granted and secured' to them 'by the constitution and laws of the United States.' 
 
 The next eight counts are a repetition of the first eight, except that, instead of the words 'band together,' the words 'combine, conspire, and confederate together' are used. Three of the defendants were found guilty under the first sixteen counts, and not guilty under the remaining counts. [92 U.S. 542, 546] The parties thus convicted moved in arrest of judgment on the following grounds:-- 
 
 
 It was a civil rights case, and the third time that the supreme court declared that the rights enshrined in the bill of rights were not granted by the governement in the bill of rights but merely recognised there. The two that came before this one did not specifically state that those rights were pre-existing, they both stated merely that they were "natural rights" and one court pointed out that the rights within the bill of rights could not be repealed without repealing the entire bill of rights, essentially removing the concept of natural rights from american governemt (think about that real hard before you advocate modifying the bill of rights, you can't just remove one, they all have to go).
